name: GS98-9V8
title: Active - Azure Virtual Desktop reduction in the diagnostic data
summary: Impact Statement: Starting at 18:46 UTC on 16 Sep 2024, customers using Azure Virtual Desktop may notice a reduction in the diagnostic data we collect. This is a temporary adjustment aimed at stabilizing our backend databases as part of our ongoing investigation into the issues stemming from incident 1LG8-1X0.
header: Your service might have been impacted by an Azure service issue

updates.summary:
Impact Statement: Starting at 18:46 UTC on 16 Sep 2024, customers using Azure Virtual Desktop may notice a reduction in the diagnostic data we collect. This is a temporary adjustment aimed at stabilizing our backend databases as part of our ongoing investigation into the issues stemming from incident 1LG8-1X0.

 

Current status: The decision to reduce diagnostics collection is a precaution to avoid a recurrence of the challenges we faced during that incident. One of the triggers of the incident was traced to an overload of data being written to database replicas, which triggered delays, automatic failovers, and ultimately led to a database outage. By temporarily limiting the amount of diagnostic data captured, we are reducing the load on the databases and mitigating potential replication issues, thus improving service stability.

 

This is a temporary solution until we roll out a permanent fix.

 

The diagnostics that we will no longer be ingesting are exclusive to "Feed and management diagnostics". One of the triggers of the incident was a degradation in the speed at which data was written to database replicas, which triggered delays, automatic failovers, and ultimately led to a database outage.

 

We are still working on the long term fix, and will provide a status update on its development by November 15, 2024, or sooner as events warrant.

We previously reported this issue as mitigated, however, on further inspection we can confirm that the issue is still active and being investigated. We apologize for the inconvenience.

What happened?

Between 18:46 UTC on 16 Sep 2024, and 21:43 UTC on 20 October 2024, customers using Azure Virtual Desktop may have noticed a reduction in the diagnostic data we collect. This was a temporary adjustment aimed at stabilizing our backend databases as part of our previously ongoing investigation into the issues stemming from incident 1LG8-1X0.


Current Status: This incident has been mitigated. More information will be provided shortly.

One of the triggers of the incident was traced to an overload of data being written to database replicas, which triggered delays, automatic failovers, and ultimately led to a database outage. By temporarily limiting the amount of diagnostic data captured, we are reducing the load on the databases and mitigating potential replication issues, thus improving service stability.

 

This is a temporary solution until we roll out a permanent fix.

 

The diagnostics that we will no longer be ingesting are exclusive to "Feed and management diagnostics". One of the triggers of the incident was a degradation in the speed at which data was written to database replicas, which triggered delays, automatic failovers, and ultimately led to a database outage. We are working on a fix and a rollout. We will provide an update by 28 October 2024.

One of the triggers of the incident was a degradation in the speed at which data was written to database replicas, which triggered delays, automatic failovers, and ultimately led to a database outage.

 

We are still working on the long term fix, and will provide a status update on its development by November 15, 2024, or sooner as events warrant.

We previously reported this issue as mitigated, however, on further inspection we can confirm that the issue is still active and being investigated. We apologize for the inconvenience.

name: 0NTJ-VV8
title: Post Incident Review (PIR) – App Service – Intermittent HTTP 500-level response codes, timeouts, or high latency in Southeast Asia
summary: What happened?
header: Your service might have been impacted by an Azure service issue

updates.summary:
What happened?

Between 04:06 UTC and 05:14 UTC on 5 September 2024, you were identified as a customer using App Service in the Southeast Asia region, who may have received intermittent HTTP 500-level response codes, experienced timeouts or high latency when accessing App Service (Web, Mobile, and API Apps), App Service (Linux), or Function deployments hosted in this region.


What went wrong and why?

We identified that the incident was due to an exceptionally high load on the scale unit, caused by a Distributed Denial-of-Service (DDoS) attack. This intense load spanned from approximately 04:06 UTC to 05:14 UTC. During these times of elevated load, our automated throttling system activates to safeguard organic and compliant traffic by discarding packets from clients exceeding specified limits. In a multitenant setup like App Service, such scenarios can occur. In this occurrence, the load balancer virtual machines were overloaded and degraded in health until further mitigation steps were taken.


How did we respond?

We took action to block/reduce the incoming request load.

  • 04:06 UTC on 5 September 2024 – Customer impact began.
  • 04:25 UTC on 5 September 2024 – Issue was detected via Service monitoring.
  • 04:35 UTC on 5 September 2024 – Contributing cause factor identified.
  • 05:14 UTC on 5 September 2024 – Service restored, and customer impact mitigated.


How are we making incidents like this less likely or less impactful?

We work diligently to protect applications from being affected by unexpected increases in load. Among the actions we take include continuous monitoring and adjustment of settings used to drop undesired traffic without affecting legitimate traffic. We take learnings from incidents like this to further evaluate and refine our limits described above.


How can customers make incidents like this less impactful?

  • Consider reviewing our best practices surrounding App Service high availability and disaster recovery, to minimize the impact from incidents like this one: https://learn.microsoft.com/azure/reliability/reliability-app-service
  • More generally, consider evaluating the reliability of your applications using guidance from the Azure Well-Architected Framework and its interactive Well-Architected Review: https://aka.ms/AzPIR/WAF
  • The impact times above represent the full incident duration, so are not specific to any individual customer. Actual impact to service availability varied between customers and resources – for guidance on implementing monitoring to understand granular impact: https://aka.ms/AzPIR/Monitoring
  • Finally, consider ensuring that the right people in your organization will be notified about any future service issues – by configuring Azure Service Health alerts. These can trigger emails, SMS, push notifications, webhooks, and more: https://aka.ms/AzPIR/Alerts


How can we make our incident communications more useful?

You can rate this PIR and provide any feedback using our quick 3-question survey: https://aka.ms/AzPIR/0NTJ-VV8

name: ZS10-TR8
title: App Service – Erroneous 404 failures in alerts and logs – Mitigated
summary: What happened?
header: Your service might have been impacted by an Azure service issue

updates.summary:
What happened?

Between 10:01 UTC on 28 October 2024 and 18:07 UTC on 01 November 2024, a subset of customers using App Service may have experienced erroneous 404 failure notifications for the Microsoft.Web/sites/workflows API from alerts and recorded into their logs.

What we know so far?

We identified a previous change to a backend service which caused backend operations to be called to apps incorrectly.

How did we respond?

We were alerted to this issue via customer reports and responded to investigate. We applied steps to limit the erroneous failures to alleviate additional erroneous alerts and logging of these. Additionally, we’ve taken steps to revert the previous change.

What happens next?

  • To request a Post Incident Review (PIR), impacted customers can use the “Request PIR” feature within Azure Service Health. (Note: We're in the process of transitioning from "Root Cause Analyses (RCAs)" to "Post Incident Reviews (PIRs)", so you may temporarily see both terms used interchangeably in the Azure portal and in Service Health alerts.)
  • To get notified if a PIR is published, and/or to stay informed about future Azure service issues, make sure that you configure and maintain Azure Service Health alerts – these can trigger emails, SMS, push notifications, webhooks, and more: https://aka.ms/ash-alerts.
  • For more information on Post Incident Reviews, refer to https://aka.ms/AzurePIRs.
  • Finally, for broader guidance on preparing for cloud incidents, refer to https://aka.ms/incidentreadiness.

Impact Statement: Starting at 10:01 UTC on 28 October 2024, a subset of customers using App Service may have experienced erroneous 404 failure notifications for the Microsoft.Web/sites/workflows API from alerts and recorded into their logs.

Current Status: We have applied steps to limit the erroneous failures to alleviate additional erroneous alerts and logging of these. Additionally, we’re taking steps to revert a previous change which caused backend operations to be called to apps incorrectly. We’ll provide an update within the next 2 hours or as events warrant.

  • To get notified if a PIR is published, and/or to stay informed about future Azure service issues, make sure that you configure and maintain Azure Service Health alerts – these can trigger emails, SMS, push notifications, webhooks, and more: https://aka.ms/ash-alerts.
  • For more information on Post Incident Reviews, refer to https://aka.ms/AzurePIRs.
  • Finally, for broader guidance on preparing for cloud incidents, refer to https://aka.ms/incidentreadiness.

Impact Statement: Starting at 10:01 UTC on 28 October 2024, a subset of customers using App Service may have experienced erroneous 404 failure notifications for the Microsoft.Web/sites/workflows API from alerts and recorded into their logs.

Current Status: We have applied steps to limit the erroneous failures to alleviate additional erroneous alerts and logging of these. Additionally, we’re taking steps to revert a previous change which caused backend operations to be called to apps incorrectly. We’ll provide an update within the next 2 hours or as events warrant.

description:
What happened?

Between 10:01 UTC on 28 October 2024 and 18:07 UTC on 01 November 2024, a subset of customers using App Service may have experienced erroneous 404 failure notifications for the Microsoft.Web/sites/workflows API from alerts and recorded into their logs.

What we know so far?

We identified a previous change to a backend service which caused backend operations to be called to apps incorrectly.

How did we respond?

We were alerted to this issue via customer reports and responded to investigate. We applied steps to limit the erroneous failures to alleviate additional erroneous alerts and logging of these. Additionally, we’ve taken steps to revert the previous change.

What happens next?

  • To request a Post Incident Review (PIR), impacted customers can use the “Request PIR” feature within Azure Service Health. (Note: We're in the process of transitioning from "Root Cause Analyses (RCAs)" to "Post Incident Reviews (PIRs)", so you may temporarily see both terms used interchangeably in the Azure portal and in Service Health alerts.)
  • To get notified if a PIR is published, and/or to stay informed about future Azure service issues, make sure that you configure and maintain Azure Service Health alerts – these can trigger emails, SMS, push notifications, webhooks, and more: https://aka.ms/ash-alerts.

  • Finally, for broader guidance on preparing for cloud incidents, refer to https://aka.ms/incidentreadiness.

name: KSYM-9_8
title: Post Incident Review (PIR) – Data ingestion latency and incorrect alert activation
summary: What happened?
header: Your service might have been impacted by an Azure service issue

updates.summary:
What happened?

Between 09:39 UTC and 16:00 UTC on 5 September 2024, a platform issue resulted in intermittent data ingestion latency and incorrect alert activation for the following services in the Southeast Asia region:

  • Log Analytics
  • Application Insights
  • Microsoft Azure Sentinel


What went wrong, and why?

Due to a throttling configuration issue on a storage unit utilized by the underlying Log Analytics pipeline, the service experienced aggressive throttling, which caused an increase of request failures in dependent storage in the Southeast Asia region. These failures impacted the throughput of processing components that distribute data that downstream services read and export, causing the distribution of data to bottleneck, ultimately delaying the processing of applicable data relied upon by the affected services.

 

How did we respond?

  • 09:39 UTC on 05 September 2024 – Storage request failures began to increase.
  • 09:40 UTC on 05 September 2024 - Our automated service monitoring detected an unusual trend in workspace latency in the region, alerting engineering to investigate.
  • 10:06 UTC on 05 September 2024 – We identified the throughput of data movement was slowed and found the unhealthy storage and configuration error.
  • 13:04 UTC on 05 September 2024 – We completed scaling out processing components to improve the throughput of the service handling incoming requests.
  • 14:00 UTC on 05 September 2024 – Started load balancing to redistribute the traffic to other healthy resources.
  • 16:00 UTC on 05 September 2024 – Data movement latency returned to acceptable levels, followed by dependent alerts firing as expected.


How are we making incidents like this less likely or less impactful?

  • Improve automated scaling of processing components to help prevent throughput impact in the case of storage requests failing. (Estimated completion: October 2024)
  • Further optimization of request failure handling to help improve the efficiency and reliability of data processing when issues may arise. (Estimated completion: October 2024)
  • Enhance load balancing effectiveness to help ensure healthy resources can handle redirected traffic from unhealthy components to prevent potential bottlenecks or delay in the processing pipeline. (Estimated completion: March 2025)


How can customers make incidents like this less impactful?

  • Consider evaluating the reliability of your applications using guidance from the Azure Well-Architected Framework and its interactive Well-Architected Review: https://aka.ms/AzPIR/WAF
  • The impact times above represent the full incident duration, so are not specific to any individual customer. Actual impact to service availability varied between customers and resources – for guidance on implementing monitoring to understand granular impact: https://aka.ms/AzPIR/Monitoring
  • Finally, consider ensuring that the right people in your organization will be notified about any future service issues – by configuring Azure Service Health alerts. These can trigger emails, SMS, push notifications, webhooks, and more: https://aka.ms/AzPIR/Alerts


How can we make our incident communications more useful?


You can rate this PIR and provide any feedback using our quick 3-question survey.

name: 1KFM-DQ0
title: Post Incident Review (PIR) – Entra ID Application – Permissions management issues
summary: What happened?
header: Your service might have been impacted by an Azure service issue

updates.summary:
What happened?

You were identified among a subset of Entra ID application customers trying to update application configurations that target consumer accounts, who may have experienced problems saving configuration changes. Updates may have failed through the user interface as well as via APIs, between 19:00 UTC on 8 September 2024 and 04:40 UTC on 12 September 2024. Authentications were not impacted. While this issue impacted less than 15% of Microsoft Entra Permissions Management operations during this time period, unfortunately it impacted one or more of your Azure subscriptions. That’s why we’re providing you with this Post Incident Review (PIR) – to summarize what went wrong, how we responded, and the steps Microsoft is taking to learn from this and improve.


What went wrong and why?

Updates to app configurations in Entra ID that targeted consumer apps failed to save to the backend. These updates are encrypted prior to being saved; however this process began failing because the encryption key that was being used had been revoked. Because there was no other available key to perform the encryption, these updates failed to save properly. This key revocation was a planned routine activity and was not due to any security incident.

How did we respond?

This incident was initially reported to us by an impacted customer, as our current monitoring did not include this scenario. The mitigation involved providing a new valid encryption key for Entra ID to utilize for saving app configurations for consumer apps. A new key was rolled out globally in a gradual fashion, and 99.9% of customers recovered within 6 hours. Full recovery was achieved about 24 hours later.


How are we making incidents like this less likely or less impactful?

  • We have repaired the process that provides the required encryption key to Entra ID, to avoid having keys revoked while still in use. (Completed)
  • We are updating our monitoring so that we are notified if the process that provides encryption keys is unhealthy. (Estimated completion: September 2024)
  • Finally, we are hardening this process to make it more resilient to issues that impact our encryption key handling. (Estimated completion: October 2024)


How can customers make incidents like this less impactful?

  • There was nothing that customers could have done to prevent or minimize impact from this specific incident.
  • More generally, consider evaluating the reliability of your applications using guidance from the Azure Well-Architected Framework and its interactive Well-Architected Review: https://aka.ms/AzPIR/WAF
  • The impact times above represent the full incident duration, so are not specific to any individual customer. Actual impact to service availability varied between customers and resources – for guidance on implementing monitoring to understand granular impact: https://aka.ms/AzPIR/Monitoring
  • Finally, consider ensuring that the right people in your organization will be notified about any future service issues – by configuring Azure Service Health alerts. These can trigger emails, SMS, push notifications, webhooks, and more: https://aka.ms/AzPIR/Alerts


How can we make our incident communications more useful?

You can rate this PIR and provide any feedback using our quick 3-question survey: https://aka.ms/AzPIR/1KFM-DQ0

This notification is for previously scheduled maintenance to your Azure Database for PostgreSQL instance(s) in Southeast Asia. Maintenance will start at 09:00 UTC on 13 Nov 2024 (17:00 Malay Peninsula Standard Time on 13 Nov 2024) and expected to complete by 00:00 UTC on 14 Nov 2024 (08:00 Malay Peninsula Standard Time on 14 Nov 2024). During maintenance, your Azure Database for PostgreSQL instance(s) may experience a brief drop in connectivity for a short number of seconds. Feel free to refer to your portal for more information (https://aka.ms/servicehealthpm) and for any additional questions, please contact support.

Impacted Resources

This notification is for upcoming planned maintenance to your Azure Database for PostgreSQL instance(s) in Southeast Asia. This is scheduled to occur between 09:00 UTC on 13 Nov 2024 (17:00 Malay Peninsula Standard Time on 13 Nov 2024) and 00:00 UTC on 14 Nov 2024 (08:00 Malay Peninsula Standard Time on 14 Nov 2024). During planned maintenance on your Azure Database for PostgreSQL instance(s), there can be database server restarts or failovers, which might lead to brief (60-120 seconds) unavailability of the database servers for end users. The entire planned maintenance event including each server restarts is carefully monitored by the engineering team. The server failovers time is dependent on database recovery time, which can cause the database to come online in minutes to hours if you have high transactional activity on the server at the time of failover. To avoid longer unavailability time, it is recommended to keep transactional workload light and defer long-running transactions like create index or data load to minimize disruptions to your application. Refer to (planned maintenance notification) for more details. Feel free to refer to your portal for more information (https://aka.ms/servicehealthpm) and for any additional questions, please contact support.

The Azure Database for PostgreSQL Single Server retirement was announced on 31 March 2023 and you need to move to Azure Database for Flexible server PostgreSQL by March 2025. We highly recommend you to get started and migrate to Flexible server as soon as possible using the Single to Flexible migration tool available on the Azure Portal as well as Azure CLI.

Impacted Resources

name: PMC0-PQ8
title: Migrate Azure Database for PostgreSQL Single Servers that use PostgreSQL version 11 to Flexible Server by 28 March 2025
summary: You're receiving this notice because you have Azure Database for PostgreSQL Single Servers that use PostgreSQL version 11.
header: Your service might have been impacted by an Azure service issue

updates.summary:
You're receiving this notice because you have Azure Database for PostgreSQL Single Servers that use PostgreSQL version 11.

Because community support for PostgreSQL version 11 will end on 9 November 2023, you'll need to migrate your Azure Database for PostgreSQL Single Servers that use version 11 to version 13 or higher on Flexible Server.

To ensure you have enough time to make this change, Azure Database for PostgreSQL will continue to support version 11 on Single Server for an additional year, through 28 March 2025, including creating new servers. After that date, restrictions will apply.

Flexible Server provides several improvements over Single Server, including:

  2. For Issue type, select Technical.
  3. For Subscription, select your subscription.
  4. For Service, select My services.
  5. For Service type, select Azure Database for PostgreSQL flexible server.
  6. For Resource, select the resource you need help with.
  7. For Problem type, select Migrating to Azure DB for PostgreSQL.
  8. For Problem subtype, select Migrating from Single Server to Flexible Server.

Learn more about service retirements that may impact your resources in the Azure Retirement Workbook. Please note that retirements may not be visible in the workbook for up to two weeks after being announced.

You're receiving this notice because you have Azure Database for PostgreSQL Single Servers that use PostgreSQL version 11.

Because community support for PostgreSQL version 11 will end on 9 November 2023, you'll need to migrate your Azure Database for PostgreSQL Single Servers that use version 11 to version 13 or higher on Flexible Server.

To ensure you have enough time to make this change, Azure Database for PostgreSQL will continue to support version 11 on Single Server for an additional year, through 28 March 2025, including creating new servers. After that date, restrictions will apply.

Flexible Server provides several improvements over Single Server, including:

  • Built-in cost optimization.
  • Simplified deployment experience.
  • Granular control over your databases.
  • Support for the most recent PostgreSQL versions.

Required action

To avoid any disruption to your workloads, migrate your Azure Database for PostgreSQL Single Servers that use version 11 to version 13 or higher on Flexible Server by 28 March 2025.

  6. For Resource, select the resource you need help with.
  7. For Problem type, select Migrating to Azure DB for PostgreSQL.
  8. For Problem subtype, select Migrating from Single Server to Flexible Server.

Learn more about service retirements that may impact your resources in the Azure Retirement Workbook. Please note that retirements may not be visible in the workbook for up to two weeks after being announced.

You're receiving this notice because you have Azure Database for PostgreSQL Single Servers that use PostgreSQL version 11.

Because community support for PostgreSQL version 11 will end on 9 November 2023, you'll need to migrate your Azure Database for PostgreSQL Single Servers that use version 11 to version 13 or higher on Flexible Server.

To ensure you have enough time to make this change, Azure Database for PostgreSQL will continue to support version 11 on Single Server for an additional year, through 28 March 2025, including creating new servers. After that date, restrictions will apply.

Flexible Server provides several improvements over Single Server, including:

  • Built-in cost optimization.
  • Simplified deployment experience.
  • Granular control over your databases.
  • Support for the most recent PostgreSQL versions.

Required action

To avoid any disruption to your workloads, migrate your Azure Database for PostgreSQL Single Servers that use version 11 to version 13 or higher on Flexible Server by 28 March 2025.

  5. For Service type, select Azure Database for PostgreSQL flexible server.

name: CL84-JF0
title: We're extending promotional discounts on Azure Databricks serverless compute services
summary: You're receiving this notification because you currently use Azure Databricks.
header: Your service might have been impacted by an Azure service issue

updates.summary:
You're receiving this notification because you currently use Azure Databricks.

We're extending promotional discounts on Azure Databricks serverless compute for notebooks, jobs, and pipelines from 31 October 2024 to 31 January 2025. Until that date, you'll continue to get 50% off serverless compute for jobs and pipelines, plus 30% off serverless compute for notebooks.

Serverless compute provides rapid workload startup, automatic infrastructure scaling, and seamless version upgrades of the Azure Databricks runtime.

After 31 January 2025, pricing for serverless compute services will return to the regular rate. For more details, check our Azure Databricks pricing page and use the filters to explore pricing by region.

Help and support

If you have questions, get answers from community experts in Microsoft Q&A.

If you have a support plan and you need technical help, open the Azure portal and select the question mark icon at the top of the page.

name: ZMD1-RF0
title: Important notice: Upcoming billing changes for serverless networking
summary: You're receiving this notification because you currently use Azure Databricks.
header: Your service might have been impacted by an Azure service issue

updates.summary:
You're receiving this notification because you currently use Azure Databricks.

Starting 4 December 2024, we'll begin charging for networking costs for serverless workloads connecting to external resources. Billing will be implemented on a gradual schedule, and you may not be charged until after 4 December 2024. Additionally, you won't be charged retroactively for usage that occurs before billing is enabled.

Once billing is enabled, you'll be charged for:

  1. Private connectivity to your resources over Private Link, including data processing and per-hour charges. Currently, Private Link data processed charges are waived.
  2. Public connectivity to your resources over NAT gateway.
  3. Data transfer charges incurred, such as when serverless compute and the target resource are in different regions.

For more details about the impact of this change, review our FAQ, pricing, and timeline.

Help and support

If you have questions, get answers from community experts in Microsoft Q&A. If you have a support plan and you need technical help, open the Azure portal and select the question mark icon at the top of the page.

  3. Data transfer charges incurred, such as when serverless compute and the target resource are in different regions.

For more details about the impact of this change, review our FAQ, pricing, and timeline.

Help and support

If you have questions, get answers from community experts in Microsoft Q&A. If you have a support plan and you need technical help, open the Azure portal and select the question mark icon at the top of the page.

You're receiving this notification because you currently use Azure Databricks.

Starting 4 December 2024, we'll begin charging for networking costs for serverless workloads connecting to external resources. Billing will be implemented on a gradual schedule, and you may not be charged until after 4 December 2024. Additionally, you won't be charged retroactively for usage that occurs before billing is enabled.

name: KMCW-NQ0
title: Azure Database for PostgreSQL Single Server will be retired on 28 March 2025
summary: You’re receiving this notification because you use Azure Database for PostgreSQL - Single Server.
header: Your service might have been impacted by an Azure service issue

updates.summary:
You’re receiving this notification because you use Azure Database for PostgreSQL - Single Server.

On 28 March 2025, Azure Database for PostgreSQL - Single Server will be retired, and you’ll need to migrate to Azure Database for PostgreSQL - Flexible Server by that date. As part of this change, we would like to offer: 

  1. Guidance and Migration tools to use. 
  2. Support as you migrate.

Please Refer to the retirement announcement for Azure Database for PostgreSQL - Single Server.

Required action

To avoid any disruptions in service, use the migration tool to migrate to Azure Database for PostgreSQL - Flexible Server as soon as possible. Read the FAQ to learn more.

Help and support

If you have a support plan and you need technical help, please create a support request.

  2. Support as you migrate.

Please Refer to the retirement announcement for Azure Database for PostgreSQL - Single Server.

Required action

To avoid any disruptions in service, use the migration tool to migrate to Azure Database for PostgreSQL - Flexible Server as soon as possible. Read the FAQ to learn more.

Help and support

If you have a support plan and you need technical help, please create a support request.

name: GNYS-3V8
title: Update on retirement of TLS 1.0 and TLS 1.1 versions for Azure Services
summary: Following the announcement on 10 November 2023, we’re continuing our transition to requiring TLS 1.2 or later for all connections to Azure services.
header: Your service might have been impacted by an Azure service issue

updates.summary:
Following the announcement on 10 November 2023, we’re continuing our transition to requiring TLS 1.2 or later for all connections to Azure services.

To minimize disruption to customer workloads, several services will continue supporting TLS 1.0 and TLS 1.1 versions and complete their transitions by 31 August 2025 when TLS 1.2 or later will be required for all connections to Azure services (unless explicitly indicated in service documentation). The list of remaining services will be updated as transitions to TLS 1.2 or later complete. 

While the Microsoft implementation of TLS 1.0 and TLS 1.1 versions isn’t known to have vulnerabilities, TLS 1.2 or later versions provide improved security features, including perfect forward secrecy and stronger cipher suites. 

Customers still using TLS 1.0 or 1.1 should transition their workloads to TLS 1.2 or later versions to ensure uninterrupted connectivity to Azure services.  

Recommended action

To avoid potential service disruptions, confirm that your resources that interact with Azure services are using TLS 1.2 or later. Then:

  • If they're already exclusively using TLS 1.2 or later, you don't need to take further action.
  • If they still have a dependency on TLS 1.0 or 1.1, transition them to TLS 1.2 or later.

Help and support

Read more about the update to TLS 1.2. If you have questions, get answers from community experts in Microsoft Q&A. If you have a support plan and you need technical help, please create a support request.

Learn more about service retirements that may impact your resources in the Azure Retirement Workbook. Please note that retirements may not be visible in the workbook for up to two weeks after being announced.

  • If they still have a dependency on TLS 1.0 or 1.1, transition them to TLS 1.2 or later.

Help and support

Read more about the update to TLS 1.2. If you have questions, get answers from community experts in Microsoft Q&A. If you have a support plan and you need technical help, please create a support request.

Learn more about service retirements that may impact your resources in the Azure Retirement Workbook. Please note that retirements may not be visible in the workbook for up to two weeks after being announced.

Following the announcement on 10 November 2023, we’re continuing our transition to requiring TLS 1.2 or later for all connections to Azure services.

To minimize disruption to customer workloads, several services will continue supporting TLS 1.0 and TLS 1.1 versions and complete their transitions by 31 August 2025 when TLS 1.2 or later will be required for all connections to Azure services (unless explicitly indicated in service documentation). The list of remaining services will be updated as transitions to TLS 1.2 or later complete. 

While the Microsoft implementation of TLS 1.0 and TLS 1.1 versions isn’t known to have vulnerabilities, TLS 1.2 or later versions provide improved security features, including perfect forward secrecy and stronger cipher suites. 

Customers still using TLS 1.0 or 1.1 should transition their workloads to TLS 1.2 or later versions to ensure uninterrupted connectivity to Azure services.  

Recommended action

To avoid potential service disruptions, confirm that your resources that interact with Azure services are using TLS 1.2 or later. Then:

  • If they're already exclusively using TLS 1.2 or later, you don't need to take further action.
  • If they still have a dependency on TLS 1.0 or 1.1, transition them to TLS 1.2 or later.

Customers still using TLS 1.0 or 1.1 should transition their workloads to TLS 1.2 or later versions to ensure uninterrupted connectivity to Azure services.  

Recommended action

To avoid potential service disruptions, confirm that your resources that interact with Azure services are using TLS 1.2 or later. Then:

  • If they're already exclusively using TLS 1.2 or later, you don't need to take further action.
  • If they still have a dependency on TLS 1.0 or 1.1, transition them to TLS 1.2 or later.

Help and support

Read more about the update to TLS 1.2. If you have questions, get answers from community experts in Microsoft Q&A. If you have a support plan and you need technical help, please create a support request.

Learn more about service retirements that may impact your resources in the Azure Retirement Workbook. Please note that retirements may not be visible in the workbook for up to two weeks after being announced.

description:
Following the announcement on 10 November 2023, we’re continuing our transition to requiring TLS 1.2 or later for all connections to Azure services.

To minimize disruption to customer workloads, several services will continue supporting TLS 1.0 and TLS 1.1 versions and complete their transitions by 31 August 2025 when TLS 1.2 or later will be required for all connections to Azure services (unless explicitly indicated in service documentation). The list of remaining services will be updated as transitions to TLS 1.2 or later complete. 

While the Microsoft implementation of TLS 1.0 and TLS 1.1 versions isn’t known to have vulnerabilities, TLS 1.2 or later versions provide improved security features, including perfect forward secrecy and stronger cipher suites. 

Customers still using TLS 1.0 or 1.1 should transition their workloads to TLS 1.2 or later versions to ensure uninterrupted connectivity to Azure services.  

Recommended action

To avoid potential service disruptions, confirm that your resources that interact with Azure services are using TLS 1.2 or later. Then:

  • If they're already exclusively using TLS 1.2 or later, you don't need to take further action.
  • If they still have a dependency on TLS 1.0 or 1.1, transition them to TLS 1.2 or later.

Help and support

Read more about the update to TLS 1.2. If you have questions, get answers from community experts in Microsoft Q&A. If you have a support plan and you need technical help, please create a support request.

Learn more about service retirements that may impact your resources in the Azure Retirement Workbook. Please note that retirements may not be visible in the workbook for up to two weeks after being announced.

name: LSHT-7W8
title: Azure Database for PostgreSQL Single Server will be retired—migrate to Flexible Server by 28 March 2025
summary: You’re receiving this notice because you use Azure Database for PostgreSQL Single Server.
header: Your service might have been impacted by an Azure service issue

updates.summary:
You’re receiving this notice because you use Azure Database for PostgreSQL Single Server.

On 28 March 2025, Azure Database for PostgreSQL Single Server will be retired, and you'll need to migrate to Azure Database for PostgreSQL Flexible Server by that date. Additionally, as part of this change:

  • Beginning 31 March 2023, you’ll no longer be able to create new Single Server instances for PostgreSQL versions 10 and older through the Azure portal.
  • Beginning 9 November 2023, you’ll no longer be able to create new Single Server instances for PostgreSQL version 11 through the Azure portal.

When you migrate to Azure Database for PostgreSQL Flexible Server, you’ll have access to multiple improvements, including:

  • Support for Postgres version 11 and newer, plus built-in security enhancements.
  • Better price-performance with support for burstable tier compute options.
  • Improved uptime with the ability to configure a hot standby on the same or a different zone and user-controlled maintenance windows.
  • A simplified developer experience for high-performance data workloads.

Required action

To avoid any disruptions in service, use the migration tool to migrate to Azure Database for PostgreSQL Flexible Server by 28 March 2025. Read the FAQ to learn more.

Help and support

If you have questions, get answers from community experts in Microsoft Q&A. If you have a support plan and you need technical help, please create a support request:

  1. For Issue type, select Technical.
  2. For Subscription, select your subscription.
  3. For Service, select My services.
  4. For Service type, select Azure Database for PostgreSQL single server.
  5. For Resource, select your resource.
  6. For Summary, type a description of your issue.
  7. For Problem type, select Migrating to Azure DB for PostgreSQL.
  8. For Problem subtype, select Issues migrating from single to flexible server.

You’re receiving this notice because you use Azure Database for PostgreSQL Single Server.

On 28 March 2025, Azure Database for PostgreSQL Single Server will be retired, and you'll need to migrate to Azure Database for PostgreSQL Flexible Server by that date. Additionally, as part of this change:

  • Beginning 31 March 2023, you’ll no longer be able to create new Single Server instances for PostgreSQL versions 10 and older through the Azure portal.
  • Beginning 9 November 2023, you’ll no longer be able to create new Single Server instances for PostgreSQL version 11 through the Azure portal.

When you migrate to Azure Database for PostgreSQL Flexible Server, you’ll have access to multiple improvements, including:

  • Support for Postgres version 11 and newer, plus built-in security enhancements.
  • Better price-performance with support for burstable tier compute options.
  • Improved uptime with the ability to configure a hot standby on the same or a different zone and user-controlled maintenance windows.
  • A simplified developer experience for high-performance data workloads.

Required action

To avoid any disruptions in service, use the migration tool to migrate to Azure Database for PostgreSQL Flexible Server by 28 March 2025. Read the FAQ to learn more.

name: 1VFH-NR8
title: Retirement notice: VPN Gateway non-AZ SKUs will be retired on 16 November 2026
summary: You're receiving this notice because you're currently using VPN Gateway with VpnGw1–5.
header: Your service might have been impacted by an Azure service issue

updates.summary:
You're receiving this notice because you're currently using VPN Gateway with VpnGw1–5.

On 16 September 2026, VPN Gateway non-AZ SKUs will be retired and automatically migrated to AZ SKUs. Because we're preparing for this change, you won't be able to create new gateways on VpnGw1–5 SKUs after 31 December 2024. 

We're retiring these SKUs because they lack redundancy, have lower availability, and are potentially more expensive because they require additional failover solutions. 

To assist with this migration, we're lowering pricing on AZ SKUs beginning on 1 January 2025.

Help and support 

To view your impacted resources in the Azure portal, navigate to Azure VPN Gateway (except Standard and High-Performance SKUs, which aren't impacted).

If you have questions, ask community experts in Microsoft Q&A. If you have a support plan and you need technical help, create a support request.

Learn more about service retirements that may impact your resources in the Azure Retirement Workbook. Please note that retirements may not be visible in the workbook for up to two weeks after being announced.

On 16 September 2026, VPN Gateway non-AZ SKUs will be retired and automatically migrated to AZ SKUs. Because we're preparing for this change, you won't be able to create new gateways on VpnGw1–5 SKUs after 31 December 2024. 

We're retiring these SKUs because they lack redundancy, have lower availability, and are potentially more expensive because they require additional failover solutions. 

To assist with this migration, we're lowering pricing on AZ SKUs beginning on 1 January 2025.

Help and support 

To view your impacted resources in the Azure portal, navigate to Azure VPN Gateway (except Standard and High-Performance SKUs, which aren't impacted).

If you have questions, ask community experts in Microsoft Q&A. If you have a support plan and you need technical help, create a support request.

On 16 September 2026, VPN Gateway non-AZ SKUs will be retired and automatically migrated to AZ SKUs. Because we're preparing for this change, you won't be able to create new gateways on VpnGw1–5 SKUs after 31 December 2024. 

We're retiring these SKUs because they lack redundancy, have lower availability, and are potentially more expensive because they require additional failover solutions. 

To assist with this migration, we're lowering pricing on AZ SKUs beginning on 1 January 2025.

Help and support 

To view your impacted resources in the Azure portal, navigate to Azure VPN Gateway (except Standard and High-Performance SKUs, which aren't impacted).

If you have questions, ask community experts in Microsoft Q&A. If you have a support plan and you need technical help, create a support request.

Learn more about service retirements that may impact your resources in the Azure Retirement Workbook. Please note that retirements may not be visible in the workbook for up to two weeks after being announced.

name: GLSJ-LQ0
title: Retirement notice: Migrate to Azure Monitor Agent before 31 March 2026
summary: You're receiving this notice because you use the Azure Diagnostics Agent to monitor your virtual machines (VMs) or servers.
header: Your service might have been impacted by an Azure service issue

updates.summary:
You're receiving this notice because you use the Azure Diagnostics Agent to monitor your virtual machines (VMs) or servers.

On 31 March 2026, we'll retire the Azure Diagnostic Extensions for Windows and Linux (WAD/LAD) and it'll no longer be supported by Microsoft. You'll need to start using the Azure Monitor Agent to monitor your VMs and servers in Azure. The Azure Monitor Agent provides new features and capabilities, including:

  • Centralized configuration for multiple VMs.
  • Data limits and filters at the source.
  • Multiple destinations for data from a single agent. (Log Analytics, Storage, Event Hubs, and Metrics). 

Required action

Follow the set-up instructions to start using the Azure Monitor Agent to monitor your VMs and servers before 31 March 2026.

To check which extensions are installed on your VM, select Extensions + applications under Settings on your VM.

Help and support

If you have questions, ask community experts in Microsoft Q&A. If you have a support plan and need technical help, please create a support request:

  1. For Issue type, select Technical.
  2. For Subscription, select your subscription.
  3. For Service, select My services, then select Azure Monitor Agent (Linux or Windows).
  4. For Resource, select your resource.
  5. For Summary, type a description of your issue.
  6. For Problem type, select Issues migrating to Azure Monitor Agent (AMA).
  7. For Problem subtype, select the option that applies to you.

Learn more about service retirements that may impact your resources in the Azure Retirement Workbook. Please note that retirements may not be visible in the workbook for up to two weeks after being announced.

﻿Are you interested in gaining insights about Azure retirements? Join our livestream events on 24 October 2024 or 30 October 2024. Hear directly from Azure CTO Mark Russinovich and Azure Quality CVP John Sheehan. Register today!

name: HN_8-LF8
title: Retirement notice: Transition to using standard tests in Azure Monitor application insights
summary: You’re receiving this notice because you use URL ping tests for single-step availability testing in application insights.
header: Your service might have been impacted by an Azure service issue

updates.summary:
You’re receiving this notice because you use URL ping tests for single-step availability testing in application insights.

On 30 September 2026, the URL ping test capability of the application insights feature of Azure Monitor will be retired and ping tests will be removed from your resources. Before that date, you’ll need to transition to using standard tests, which also provide:

  • SSL certificate validity
  • Proactive lifetime check
  • HTTP request verb (such as GET, HEAD, POST)
  • Custom headers and custom data associated with HTTP requests

Recommended action

To ensure you can continue to run single-step availability tests in your application insights resources, review the pricing of standard tests and transition to using them before 30 September 2026. 

Help and support 

If you have questions, get answers from community experts in Microsoft Q&A. If you have a support plan and you need technical help, create a support request: 

  1. For Summary, type a description of your issue.  
  2. For Issue type, select Technical.  
  3. For Subscription, select your subscription.  
  4. For Service, select My services.  
  5. For Service type, select Application Insights.  
  6. For Problem type, select A feature that I use is deprecated and will be removed from Application Insights. 
  7. For Problem subtype, select Ping Tests are deprecated. 

Learn more about service retirements that may impact your resources in the Azure Retirement Workbook. Please note that retirements may not be visible in the workbook for up to two weeks after being announced.

You’re receiving this notice because you use URL ping tests for single-step availability testing in application insights.

On 30 September 2026, the URL ping test capability of the application insights feature of Azure Monitor will be retired and ping tests will be removed from your resources. Before that date, you’ll need to transition to using standard tests, which also provide:

  • SSL certificate validity
  • Proactive lifetime check
  • HTTP request verb (such as GET, HEAD, POST)
  • Custom headers and custom data associated with HTTP requests

Recommended action

To ensure you can continue to run single-step availability tests in your application insights resources, review the pricing of standard tests and transition to using them before 30 September 2026.

  1. For Summary, type a description of your issue.  
  2. For Issue type, select Technical.  
  3. For Subscription, select your subscription.  
  4. For Service, select My services.  
  5. For Service type, select Application Insights.  
  6. For Problem type, select A feature that I use is deprecated and will be removed from Application Insights. 
  7. For Problem subtype, select Ping Tests are deprecated. 

Learn more about service retirements that may impact your resources in the Azure Retirement Workbook. Please note that retirements may not be visible in the workbook for up to two weeks after being announced.

You’re receiving this notice because you use URL ping tests for single-step availability testing in application insights.

On 30 September 2026, the URL ping test capability of the application insights feature of Azure Monitor will be retired and ping tests will be removed from your resources. Before that date, you’ll need to transition to using standard tests, which also provide:

  • SSL certificate validity
  • Proactive lifetime check
  • HTTP request verb (such as GET, HEAD, POST)
  • Custom headers and custom data associated with HTTP requests

Recommended action

To ensure you can continue to run single-step availability tests in your application insights resources, review the pricing of standard tests and transition to using them before 30 September 2026.

name: 4NBJ-DQ0
title: Retirement notice: Network security group flow logs in Azure Network Watcher will be retired
summary: You’re receiving this notice because you’re using network security group flow logs in Azure Network Watcher.
header: Your service might have been impacted by an Azure service issue

updates.summary:
You’re receiving this notice because you’re using network security group flow logs in Azure Network Watcher.

On 30 September 2027, network security group (NSG) flow logs in Azure Network Watcher will be retired.

As part of this retirement, you’ll no longer be able to create new NSG flow logs starting 30 June 2025. We recommend migrating to virtual network flow logs in Network Watcher, which overcome the limitations of NSG flow logs and provide enhanced capabilities such as:

  • Simplified scope of enablement
  • Enhanced coverage of additional resources
  • Support for virtual network encryption

After the retirement date, traffic analytics enabled with NSG flow logs will no longer be supported, and existing NSG flow logs resources in your subscriptions will be deleted. However, NSG flow logs records won’t be deleted and will continue to follow their respective retention policies.

Required action

To avoid service disruptions, migrate to virtual network flow logs by 30 September 2027.

Help and support

If you have questions, get answers from community experts in Microsoft Q&A. If you have a support plan and you need technical help, open the Azure portal and select the question mark icon at the top of the page.  

Learn more about service retirements that may impact your resources in the Azure Retirement Workbook. Please note that retirements may not be visible in the workbook for up to two weeks after being announced.

On 30 September 2027, network security group (NSG) flow logs in Azure Network Watcher will be retired.

As part of this retirement, you’ll no longer be able to create new NSG flow logs starting 30 June 2025. We recommend migrating to virtual network flow logs in Network Watcher, which overcome the limitations of NSG flow logs and provide enhanced capabilities such as:

  • Simplified scope of enablement
  • Enhanced coverage of additional resources
  • Support for virtual network encryption

After the retirement date, traffic analytics enabled with NSG flow logs will no longer be supported, and existing NSG flow logs resources in your subscriptions will be deleted. However, NSG flow logs records won’t be deleted and will continue to follow their respective retention policies.

Required action

To avoid service disruptions, migrate to virtual network flow logs by 30 September 2027.

name: 1KFM-DQ0
title: Post Incident Review (PIR) – Entra ID Application – Permissions management issues
summary: What happened?
header: Your service might have been impacted by an Azure service issue

updates.summary:
What happened?

You were identified among a subset of Entra ID application customers trying to update application configurations that target consumer accounts, who may have experienced problems saving configuration changes. Updates may have failed through the user interface as well as via APIs, between 19:00 UTC on 8 September 2024 and 04:40 UTC on 12 September 2024. Authentications were not impacted. While this issue impacted less than 15% of Microsoft Entra Permissions Management operations during this time period, unfortunately it impacted one or more of your Azure subscriptions. That’s why we’re providing you with this Post Incident Review (PIR) – to summarize what went wrong, how we responded, and the steps Microsoft is taking to learn from this and improve.


What went wrong and why?

Updates to app configurations in Entra ID that targeted consumer apps failed to save to the backend. These updates are encrypted prior to being saved; however this process began failing because the encryption key that was being used had been revoked. Because there was no other available key to perform the encryption, these updates failed to save properly. This key revocation was a planned routine activity and was not due to any security incident.

How did we respond?

This incident was initially reported to us by an impacted customer, as our current monitoring did not include this scenario. The mitigation involved providing a new valid encryption key for Entra ID to utilize for saving app configurations for consumer apps. A new key was rolled out globally in a gradual fashion, and 99.9% of customers recovered within 6 hours. Full recovery was achieved about 24 hours later.


How are we making incidents like this less likely or less impactful?

  • We have repaired the process that provides the required encryption key to Entra ID, to avoid having keys revoked while still in use. (Completed)
  • We are updating our monitoring so that we are notified if the process that provides encryption keys is unhealthy. (Estimated completion: September 2024)
  • Finally, we are hardening this process to make it more resilient to issues that impact our encryption key handling. (Estimated completion: October 2024)


How can customers make incidents like this less impactful?

  • There was nothing that customers could have done to prevent or minimize impact from this specific incident.
  • More generally, consider evaluating the reliability of your applications using guidance from the Azure Well-Architected Framework and its interactive Well-Architected Review: https://aka.ms/AzPIR/WAF
  • The impact times above represent the full incident duration, so are not specific to any individual customer. Actual impact to service availability varied between customers and resources – for guidance on implementing monitoring to understand granular impact: https://aka.ms/AzPIR/Monitoring
  • Finally, consider ensuring that the right people in your organization will be notified about any future service issues – by configuring Azure Service Health alerts. These can trigger emails, SMS, push notifications, webhooks, and more: https://aka.ms/AzPIR/Alerts


How can we make our incident communications more useful?

You can rate this PIR and provide any feedback using our quick 3-question survey: https://aka.ms/AzPIR/1KFM-DQ0
